"Good PC version. Was patched with DX11. Performance is good with lots of graphic options. FOV is changed using console commands. Muliplayer shutdown"

Multiplayer

  • Note: As of June 2014, our friends at GameSpy have ended all hosted game services, which will affect the online multiplayer aspect of this game. Because of technical challenges and concerns, EA does not have a solution to keep these services up and running at this time, and online services for this game and other EA games on the GameSpy platform have ended.

READ MORE

About This Game



Aliens are decimating New York City, only you have the technology to survive. Adapt in real time using the unique Nanosuit 2 Stealth, Armor and Power abilities, then tackle the alien menace in ways a regular soldier could only dream of. Crysis 2 redefines the visual benchmark for console and PC platforms in the urban jungle of NYC. Be The Weapon.

Includes 4 Limited Edition unlocks:

  • Bonus XP - Access to preset classes plus a custom class
  • Scar weapon Skin - Scar assault rifle digital camouflage
  • Weapon Attachment - Day 1 access to scar hologram decoy
  • Unique Platinum Dog Tag - Display your multiplayer rank and stats

Includes Retaliation and Decimation packs:

  • Total of 9 additional Multiplayer maps supporting all game modes
  • 2 new weapons - FY71 Assault Rifle and M18 Smoke Grenade
READ MORE

System Requirements

    • OS: Windows XP, Vista or Windows 7, with the latest Service Pack
    • Processor: Intel Core 2 Duo at 2Ghz, or AMD Athlon 64 x2 2Ghz, or better
    • Memory: 2GB
    • Hard Disk Space: 9Gb
    • Video Card: NVidia 8800GT with 512Mb RAM or better, ATI 3850HD with 512Mb RAM or better
    • Sound: DirectX Compatible Sound Card
    • DirectX®: 9.0c
READ MORE

83 of 97 people (86%) found this review helpful
3

1 person found this review funny
TeamTom
2,333 products in account
293 reviews
Recommended
17.9 hrs on record
Posted: July 10
Crysis 2, like the original is a first person shooter. The game was released in early 2011. It also follows on from the plot of Crysis 1 as well. Although you don't really need to have played the original in order to follow the story. Crysis 2 was also the first game to use the CryEngine 3.

The game play has all of the regular FPS style features. You play the role of a Recon Marine, called Alcatraz. You are able to customize your weapons to match the situations you are in, as well as customizing your suite to the same too. Crysis 2 is set in New York City, which is often referred to by many as an urban jungle. This does however offer various different tactical options when it comes to planning attacks; allowing players to navigate between floors and buildings, and ruined buildings.

We also see a few changes in the Nanosuit used by our character too; this time you are able to use more than one suit power at a time, the strength and power modes have been combined into the same mode, and the stealth suit has been improved slightly.

Crysis 2 has AMAZING graphics; this could easily pass as a game being released recently. If you put all of your settings up to full, you are going to be in amazement at how good this game looks. You will need a beefy rig to keep a steady 60 fps, but my oh my it is worth it.

I sadly see no replay-ability in Crysis 2, there are the addition of a couple of difficulty modes, but to be honest; once you have played it the once, there is no reason to play it again. The single-player campaign is a decent length though - we are looking at a 18 hour long story mode which is very good for an FPS.

Thankfully I had no technical issues with Crysis 2 (unlike I did have with the original), I was able to play with every graphical setting on ultra and still had 60 frames the whole time. The only thing I will mention is there is no longer any multiplayer support since GameSpy shut it's servers down in May 2014.

If you enjoyed the first Crysis game, you will basically enjoy Crysis 2, it's the same just with even better graphics, more compelling story, and stellar FPS action and did I mention the amazing graphics? People may think £20 is a bit steep for a game of this age, however I am completely happy with this price as it almost fits into the £1/hour ratio.

1) Stay away
2) Only recommended when on sale
3) Recommended
4) Highly recommended
5) This is a must play

If you found this review helpful, please consider giving it a thumbs up. You can also find more reviews over at http://www.completingthebackloggroup.com/

Pepi 🎃
136 products in account
16 reviews
Recommended
13.2 hrs on record
Posted: August 14
Great gameplay and beautiful scenery with a terrible (bad) scenario!
That is basically Crysis 2 in one sentence. But let's go a bit further!


The good, the bad and the ugly--, I mean the derp.
  • The good :
    1. It's gameplay.

      The gameplay is what makes this game so fun to play. I'm not a huge fps fan of brainless killing and I prefer my fps to be intelligent and have a good and long interesting story. This one compensate the story part by it's very entertaining gameplay and huge variety of weapons (WICH IS GOOD FOR A FPS AM I RIGHT?). I expected this game to be more like a derp shooter where you kill everything, but I actually quite enjoyed the stealth part. But of course, the gunplay is also great.

      The stealth part is absolutely not forced nor necessary, but I found it the most interesting part for me. Hearing the soldiers screaming and being all scared is a sadist joy that I don't hide. It just feels really good to sneak around all stealthy with our superior armor and killing them in style.
      Speaking of the soldiers, there are 2 main enemies in this game. Human soldiers, and Aliens. The gameplay is quite different when facing them. When you fight soldiers, you feel like... a hunter, a predator hunting his prey. And every kills is really rewarding as you feel powerful. Op even. And feeling powerful is a good feeling (because the game is not that easy on hardest difficulty!).
      When facing the aliens, it's quite the opposite. They are numerous, strong and almost scary. This time I often choose to hide. Not because I enjoy stabbing them in the back, but because I'm genuinely scared to face them and their superiority. In this case, I feel like the hunted. Aliens also have some huge boss and they are pretty challenging.


      But all this talk about the weapons would not be enough if we don't talk about the ARMOR! Because yes, the armor has such a big role in this game. It's actually it's core mechanism. Other than having the most badass voice you ever heard for an armor, it is also packed with lot of skills and uppgrades. Stealth, superior armor, thermal vision, scanning abilities, superior jump... There are a lot of differents functions. The game is made so that you will need them at least once during the course of the game at some key parts. For instance, I often find thermal vision to be more of a gadget in most games, but here it feels really good to be able to see in heavy smoke or being able to see stealth opponents... But of course, they are usefull for the whole duration of the playthrough. Never made useless.
      How do you uppgrade your armor by the way...? Well, here is an interesting way of working. You get more energy by killing aliens! Seems easy right? But aren't they the kind of enemies you would rather avoid? Yes! That's the trick. It's easier to avoid them, but more rewarding to actually kill them!


    2. The graphics :
      Crysis 2 has always be known for being a very demanding game when it was out in 2011. And... well, even after 4 years the game is still insanely beautiful. It's not just that it is plainly "looking good" but, the scenery and the actions are absolutely brillants, unique and gorgeous. You will see some scenes in this game that you never saw before in any other games. New York having a tsunami? Huge tentacle robot coming through the ground and destroying the city? Flying island? Absolutely epic collapsing of buildings and huge explosions? Yes, this game has them all and it looks astonishing.

    3. Miscs :
      You can also customize your weapons a little bit. Always nice to have. The game lenght is pretty good if you play a bit more stealth wise and play on hardest difficulty. I would say around 17hours for me since steam misses a few hours.

  • The bad :
    1. It's story.

      Oh boy... oh boy . Well, where to start? The basic story is that Aliens are attacking earth and you are a marine in New York that is going to fight them back.
      And well, that's it! Enjoy!
      No, actualy there is a bit more. But it's just extremely cliché and uninteresting, and mostly poorly excecuted. They tried to put some "conspiracy" and "betrayals" , but the characters are so stereotyped, blank and annoying that you just can't care about what is happening to them and the story. Your own character has absolutely 0 charisma and personnality. The only "interesting character" is actually... your armor. Yup!
      The game also have a kind of repeating scenario for the whole game. Something like I'm alone >>> I found my crew! >>> I lost them and I'm almost dead D: >>> REPEAT! >>> I'm alone >>> Another crew found me!

    2. The Ai :
      The ai has in my opinion only one and major flaw. They kind of always know where you are even if they don't see you. This is extremely annoying and is a stupid way to try to artificialy increase the difficulty. How does this stupid functionality works? It's simple, even if they never see you or hear you, the ai will tend to move where you are and either, search, pattrol, or stand there like nothing. It makes them finding you unfunny and not "deserved" . This almost always happens with the humans ai. Rarely with the aliens though.

    3. The design :
      Even though the aliens are looking great, they have a major flaw. Most of them looks very close to each other so it's very hard to know if it's a "basic grunt" , or one very advanced type of aliens. Only a few ones have really unique look.

    4. The army feels :
      Here is a personal opinion. It's simple, if you love american army stuff, you will like the general feeling of the interraction with your character. If you don't, it's pretty annoying. This game has a "oh wow army is awesome we are heroes" feels and people seems proud to call you "marine" , or "soldier" at each possiblities and you know it's done because they think it's "awesome to hear it" , and it keep showing the american flags very often and other details like this. Also you're pretty much the most cliché "super soldier hero" character you can think of.

  • The derp :
    Some stuff in this game are neither impressive nor bad. Like the music. It's not bad, but there are not many and seem to repeat themselves. If you are interested in the multiplayer, know that it's not working anymore. I didn't have any glitches, expect a few enemies falling from where they were (like next to a cliff or on a window). It was more funny that annoying. I heard there are modding with this game, but I didn't try it.

Conclusion :
If you're a huge fps fan, just take it. I think it's a good game, but being now an old game with such heavy competitors.., I only reccomend it on sale for everyone else. However the game is very fun to play... and actually, isn't that the most important?

SpaceCouncil

63 reviews
Recommended
5.6 hrs on record
Posted: September 21
This is a Far Cry from the original Crysis.. is that not funny? Too soon? Anyways..

Let me explain first by telling you why Crysis 1 was far more than a tech demo. It was what marketing teams now popularly refer to as yielding something know as “emergent gameplay” Sure, I'll grant it you it was a technical showpiece when real time shadows on foliage was ground breaking not only for technical achievement but also for your wallet regarding the new GPU you'll need to run it properly.

There was real strategy to be had while playing Crysis. From cloaking yourself, sneaking behind someone and grabbing them by the throat, switching to strength mode and throwing them off a cliff. To tanking and switching in between maximum armor, strength and speed to jump over a fence and blasting unsuspecting fools with an automatic shotgun or on the fly switching between different scopes, applying a silencer, crouching, taking aim (maximum strength, to steady fire) and sniping on the fringe of a base. These are just a small percentage of what the game allowed you to do. All this was combined with a huge open terrain of varying topography.

All of this is exchanged for a easy to grasp corridor shooter in Crysis 2. Now, don't get me wrong I love a good corridor shooter but the freedom of play granted in 1 turns the “freedom” into clearly labeled things within your visor such as get up high and snipe or stealth through the sewers, leaving any guesswork or self discovery out of the picture.

I won't harp on the story of either as I don't think either are truly interesting however nor are they offensive. They are just or sort of latent. Regardless I still prefer the original narratively speaking because I believe the pacing to be a lot better as well as the mystery of what exactly is going on on the island. This is feels more like where else can we take this idea we started with.

After all this reasoning as to why I like Crysis 1 better. Crysis 2 is still worth playing. I haven't played the multiplayer but I don't play much multiplayer anything so that info is better commented on by someone else. What I can say is the gunplay feels great, combined with the exo suits abilities. I'm sure the multiplayer is as fun and competent as the campaign and certainly will extend the life if that sort of thing floats your boat.

Whiteswart
1,286 products in account
78 reviews
Not Recommended
16.1 hrs on record
Posted: October 15
I remember years 2010 and 2011, when I finally changed my hardware from P4 to something with more cores... I've played ALOT of FPS shooters then, collecting all I previously was not able to run properly. And it comes that way, that I've played the first Crysis game just before I've started the second volume.

The difference was staggering. Mind-blowing. And disastrous.

I've tried to give it the second chance lately, but alas, all that was new and good in 2011, now looks so plain and common, no juice left in that volume. Get me right: I've finished it, all the way through, on the highest difficulty. I just don't like the way I was treated all time through.

Let's speak of good things: for one, Crysis 2 has a better temper for hardware. The first Crysis caused me several BSOD during the last boss fight, but there everything was running smooth. Well, not exactly smooth, really. I'd rather use the word "Kosher", even not being a Judah's descendent myself.
I mean, everything people usually expecting from AAA shooter (like the line of CoD): variety of guns, facinating visuals, a lot of bad guys and recovering chest-high walls - all was set alright, and even more. The sound, for example, was a bull's eye shot. Hans Zimmer made a very great job, vocalizing the once-a-great-city-rumbles-into-the-abyss.

Also, to compare with the Infinity Ward products, there was much more freedom of movement and choices on the way. Quite often, there was not need to shoot at all! And new features of the trademark Nanosuit were great, without any doubts.

But there we go again to comparison with the first Crysis... and there all goes sour. Some new tricks of biosuit totally Not Worth the absence of freedom of the first game. Crysis 2 is so loosing the scales view, that it should really get another name. Totally different feeling, to the point of disgust for the "inheritor", which is not fit in dad's shoes.

And I'm not yet started with the scenario! I really felt Cevat Yerli heed too much the Breaking Bad serial. All of the scenario moves and twists leaving you with the hard uneasyness. You know, that moment in your life, where you staring at the blank wall and ask yourself "Why? oh, Why?!" I'll reveal major spoiler there: nothing is settled in the end. Nausea won't leave you after finishing the game. So it is probably the better not to start it at all.

So, let me set all said more clear:

1) The game is fine to the standards of AAA FPS - and even more, it sets some new patterns, which will be later used by many other developers. Technically all is fine, except it is a multiplatformer, so there you'll not see the real edge of technology. Just a decent picture.

2) The sights of destroyed New York... well, some people can't get enough of that, but I'm not the one of them.

3) The most notable feature of the whole game - overpowered nanosuit, is really a nice thing to use, making yourself a superbeing. Nothing comes without price, though.

4) The personality of the main character is so bleak, that nanosuit absorbs it totally. It is rancid thing. Well, the same rancid stuff goes with all scenario game pushes you through. If you care about such things, it will be an unpleasant experience.

5) Stealth feature in that game is far from I'd like to play for honing skill. Total imbalance of one-button-overall-invisibility. Nothing can see you, hear you, react to your doings while you're in "stealth" mode, which is better called "God mode". Good thing it wears off quickly, but still, total imbalance.

6) Shooting part is common. The "insurgents", I like that term there, operating quite typically: they can see and shoot you from the places where you not see them yet, they aim for the head alright, yet you mow them again and again, thanks to chest-high walls, quick regeneration, and other power armor tweaks. Overall, from the point of AI behavior and gunplay, not satysfying enough.

With all said, I set my mark as 6.95/10. There are good points in that game, even in the scenario, but they are not worth the price, in thorough look. It is a product to grab cash, after all, and not a visionary stuff, like Bioshock. If you've not bought it already, don't bother. And about "Maximum Edition"... multiplayer is dead, forget about it. Even when it worked, CoD was better there, and now we have much more variety of good multiplayer shooters, than in 2011-2012. RIP, Crysis 2.
